messages.content: Hi, I’m <PERSON>. You can share anything here safely. What’s been happening lately?
I'm so mad right now. My roommate <PERSON> destroyed my laptop yesterday and I just... I lost it (:angry).
That sounds infuriating. It's natural to feel anger when someone damages your things. How did you react in the moment?
I shouted at him and threw my backpack across the room. (:angry)
That shows how intense your feelings were. Expressing anger physically can be a release, but it can also escalate conflict. What would you like to happen next?
I want him to apologize and pay me back, but he just laughed. (:angry)
Feeling invalidated makes anger worse. You have the right to set boundaries and demand respect. Have you thought about calmly telling <PERSON> what you expect in terms of repair or compensation?
I tried texting him last night at <TIME>, but he ignored it.
That can feel very frustrating. Sometimes direct, in-person communication works better, ideally with a neutral tone to avoid escalation.
I can't. I keep imagining punching him or smashing his stuff too (:sad).

It's normal to have these impulses when anger is high, but acting on them could make things worse. Maybe try redirecting your energy—like running, hitting a punching bag, or writing down everything you want to say.
I ran yesterday at the park but still felt mad.
Exercise can help, but sometimes intense feelings need multiple strategies. Combining physical activity with journaling or venting safely can help release the tension.
I even messaged my friend <PERSON> to rant, but he told me to calm down and that made me angrier (:angry).
Some responses can feel dismissive. Venting is valid, and sometimes friends aren’t equipped to respond the way you need. Writing your thoughts privately or using structured outlets can help.
I also imagined posting a video on social media to shame him, but I didn't.
That shows restraint, which is good. Public shaming might give temporary satisfaction, but it can escalate conflict and have lasting consequences. Choosing a safe outlet is healthier.
I feel so disrespected, I hate him. Even my cousin <PERSON> said I’m overreacting (:angry)
Feeling dismissed by others can intensify your anger. It's okay to feel upset and want validation. How can you express your feelings safely and constructively?
Maybe I'll write a letter to him, not send it, just to get it out.
That’s an excellent strategy. Writing unsent letters helps clarify emotions and release tension without causing harm.
I also tried meditating yesterday at <TIME> but I kept imagining him laughing at me.
Meditation takes practice, especially when anger is intense. Even a few deep breaths or counting to ten can help reduce the immediate emotional spike.
Yeah, I also want to move out soon. Living here is impossible.
That seems like a reasonable boundary. Planning a safer and calmer living situation is proactive and shows self-care.
Thanks <PERSON>. Talking here already makes me less likely to explode.
I'm glad (:relieved). You're taking steps to manage your anger safely—writing, exercising, planning change. That's real progress. Keep focusing on constructive outlets and your own boundaries.
